content:
âœ… Approved the contribution.
Comment: Good contribution

Thank you for submitting this contribution.
I think it could be accepted, but there are a few small issues for me.
1) Similar to an existing clash:
https://www.codingame.com/contribute/view/3111bb0f7482f413b1e5388182f81bad140
Here you propose rot13.5 instead of rot13, so it may be sufficiently different to be accepted. (And you also consider lower/upper letters while the previous clash considered only uppercase letters.)

2) As already mentioned by [BadWolfe], I am not sure adding French translation is needed. If you really want to keep French text, I would recommend a few changes. I think the terminology you used is not perfect; "crypter" is not correct in French.
- des messages -> un message (for consistency with English text)
- cryptÃ©s -> chiffrÃ©s
- dÃ©crypte -> dÃ©chiffres (with 's')
- cryptage -> chiffrement
(see 4th paragraph of https://fr.wikipedia.org/wiki/Chiffrement#Terminologie )

3) As already mentioned below, I would recommend to improve the constraints.
- "0<str<150" is not correct. It looks like str is a number between 0 and 150.
What you want is: "0 < length of str < 150"
- You may want to specify which characters could be included in str. For example, the last validator contains a ':' but it is not included in any of the tests.
- "The numbers have a rotation less than the letter" should not appear in the constraints.

4) Punctuation. Please add '.' at the end of your sentences (in statement and constraints)

Comment: Well Done!!!

Interesting. I like it. But I think I need to describe what ROT13.5 is. For those who don't know. But... No... All programmers know this

Comment: Nice challenge!

Comment: Bon taf

:white_check_mark: Approved the contribution.
It remember me my fail at the exam 02 :',i like the idea of .5 :) (exam of 42 pool)

I really like the puzzle idea !

I think it would be more fairer to non native English speakers to not put the French translation.

As for the French translation, several typos ;) :
- Description : "Kevin a reÃ§u des messages cryptÃ©s de sa copine, il souhaite que tu lui dÃ©crypte. Il aurait entendu que le cryptage utilisÃ© serait le ROT13.5"
- Constraints : "Les chiffres ont une rotation infÃ©rieure Ã  celle des lettres"

Using fastest mode can be somewhat unfair if someone already knew this type of encryption, if you're really want fastest mode, you should probably explain what it is. 
Reverse mode can also be fun and easy enough, same for shortest.

Constraints description doesn't really help I feel, maybe explain the kind of input you're testing, such as letters, numbers, length of the message and so on.

I think that tests and validators must be different.
Other than that, I think its a great puzzle concept!
Tomorrow I make the modifications and I pass the subject in English and in French
Thank you I will take care of making the changes tomorrow during the day.

Since my comment is related to French language, I will switch to French. Sorry for non-French speaker. (Note: French people love to argue on everything, especially language :P)

Certes les mots existent en franÃ§ais, mais d'aprÃ¨s le Larousse:
- "crypter" est considÃ©rÃ© comme *abusif* donc je pense que ce n'est pas recommandÃ© de l'utiliser. Il est selon moi prÃ©fÃ©rable d'utiliser les mots les plus prÃ©cis possibles.
- "decrypter" a un sens lÃ©gÃ¨rement diffÃ©rent. C'est normalement utilisÃ© quand la clÃ© est inconnue; cad quand on veut attaquer un message. Dans ce cas prÃ©cis, on connait la clÃ© (13 et 5) donc "dÃ©chiffrer" est probablement plus appropriÃ©.

Mais bon, ce sont des dÃ©tails et ce n'est certainement pas le plus important.
Je suis moi-mÃªme FranÃ§ais et je peux te confirmer que ces mots sont utilisÃ©s dans le langage courant, voire technique.
